fields.description:
When creating a new issue the assigned user is sometimes lost. After clicing "Create" on CreateIssue.jspa, JIRA reports that "The issue must be assigned to someone", although a user has been selected. Selecting the user again and clicking "Create" solves the problem, although this needs to be repeated a few times.

I haven't found a real pattern when this bug occures. It occurs once every 5-10 submissions. A http log of a session when this bug occures is attached.

It works fine when using IE 5.50. Stack traces are identical in both cases.
fields.summary: JIRA "Road Map" and "Change Log" crashes under mozilla 10.

fields.description: When editing Jira configuration of our site, the field BaseURL don't accept an otherwise propper URL if it starts with https. If the URL is set via a direct insert into the database, referenses in mails and the like work, both in beeing sent with the correct URL, incl https, and that the URLs point to correct resource.
fields.summary: Edit Configuration: jira baseurl can't be https

fields.description:
The Frenchies from Quebec are using acute/grave/ circumflex accent in their descriptions !!
The export to XML in Jira does not seem to encode properly.
fields.summary: XML Export does not encode properly

fields.description:
It is often useful to link issues together (both bidirectionally and unidirectionally).

Basically you would define different 'link types' like "A blocks B <-> B blocked by A" and "A depends on B <-> B depended on by A" etc (customise any types you want). We'll provide some defaults like 'blocker' and 'dependency'.

(Should links always be bi-directional? I think so)

Then the view issue interface would display all the linked issues, with their link type (allowing you to thus easily navigate around the 'issue graph'!).

To add links, we'd provide a simple link issue interface. Basically a single select box to select link type, and either enter the issue key into a text field, or select one of your 'history' links! (See JRA-520)

It's a little like Bugzilla's 'blocker' feature, but much more powerful.
fields.summary: Issue Linking

fields.description:
It would be cool to have a browsable history list of the issues you have recently viewed. 

I often want to 'juggle' three or four issues at the one time, having a history list to jump around would be very cool.

We could have the link between Profile and Logout, to a page looking like the Manage Filters page, but with the last ~20 issues you have viewed (individually). Of course the list would be a LRU cache.
fields.summary: User history list

fields.description:
Instead of displaying all JIRA projects in a box on the left-hand side, I suggest that only the projects where you are the project lead should be displayed in a box (as it is currently) and all remaining projects displayed as a list (project name only) below that. 

This change would help in our situation where we are a team of 8 developers supporting about twenty applications, which means 20 JIRA projects, which takes up a fair amount of space. Currently you need to scroll down the home page to find the relevant project.

One way to implement this so that it does not impact on organisations with few JIRA projects is to display the projects where you are project lead first and other projects following.  If there are more than a certain number (say 5) of total projects, then the remaining projects are displayed as a list of project names.  The number of project boxes to display could be a user profile setting as it really depends on their screen resolution. This would cover all bases.
fields.summary: Suggested change to JIRA Home screen

fields.description: clicking the "del" hyperlink doesn't appear to do anything - I would expect it to remove that permission from that group.
fields.summary: "del" hyperlink on Global Permissions page doesn't work

fields.description:
In time tracking if I estimate 80 hours (which, for me is two work weeks or 10 days), JIRA changes it to 3 days 8 hours (1 day = 24 hours).  We work 8 hour days, 5 day weeks.  Would it be possible to set up the conversion for display for hours/days/weeks through a configuration of some kind.  Say that 1 day = 8 hours, 1 week = 5 days.
A configuration option might be confusing because all the display times would change if the configuration changed.  But, what if the configuration can only be changed/setup when activating time tracking...
fields.summary: Time Tracking hours/days/weeks conversion display

fields.description:
Can you please provide the captions for symbols used in various issue lists. It could be at the bottom of page. This will help user to understand the type of issue.

Thanks,
fields.summary: Captions for Symbols used

fields.description: On the new 'Find Issues' screen, you can search using dates and times.  We love the calendar, but the format it prints the dates in the text box is potentially confusing.  It is printing (for example) 1-7-2002 for today, which I am guessing is picking up somewhere that I am in the UK.  The date format used for the issues on the other hand (26/Jun/02) would be unambiguous for our friends in both the UK and the US.
fields.summary: Standardise date field format

fields.description: Add "Unclassified" to the end of the components listing on the project screen to work in the same way as "Unscheduled" does for the versions.
fields.summary: Add "Unclassifed" at the end of the components listing

fields.description:
Enhance the JIRA security permissions so you can set permissions for the following special users:
Project Lead
Assignee
Reporter

You could then for example allow: only the project lead to close the issue, or only the reporter to close the issue, or one or the other etc etc.

This would address the request to have the issue reporter close issues but in a flexible way.
fields.summary: Ehance security permissions to cater for special users

fields.description:
Sometimes you create a lot of different issues, of the same type.

We should remember the 'last issue type created' in the session - just a little nicety.
fields.summary: Remember last issue type

fields.description:
XML is not being escaped in the summary of issues shown in a list.

See http://opensource.atlassian.com/projects/webwork/secure/ViewIssue.jspa?id=10052 and then see http://opensource.atlassian.com/projects/webwork/secure/IssueNavigator.jspa?reset=true&mode=hide&sortOrder=ASC&sortColumn=priority&resolutionIds=-1&pid=10000&fixForId=-1
fields.summary: XML not escaped in lists of issues

a view-source in chimera shows "<html><body></body></html>"

but I'm not sure those are actually being received, I think IE view source showed nothing,.

It would nice to be able to share components across projects.
For instance, if i am using a component X, which was developed as part of another project, i would like people testing my project to identify component X as a troublemaker.  Then that bug can be automatically or manually sent to the project for which the component was originally developed.

fields.description:
I've been having major problems lately using Jira on Resin 2.1.2. Installation was a breeze but these appears to be problems handling transactions. Attached to this message is the error I get when I try to add a new task or issue. Each time I add a new issue, I get an error notification in the browser & a strace in the error logs, but the issues IS entered into the system (if I go back to the issue list and reload I see it there).

Note, I am also seeing this behavior when adding components or versions to a project as an admin.

BTW, my Resin datasourece and entityengine.xml is setup exactly as mentioned in the installation docs.
fields.summary: Resin transaction rollback issues

fields.description: Form field descriptions are escaped (see Setup wizard for an example) - this is bad ;)
fields.summary: Descriptions are escaped

fields.description: The SearchRequest can sometimes circumvent the security permissions for BrowseProject. Fix.
fields.summary: SearchRequest does not always respect BrowseProject permission

fields.description:
At the moment the email server / session settings are specific to the MailListener.

These settings should be global (ie stored in app properties) and then any listener can send email via a some SendMailCommand. 

That way it's easier for users to write listeners that send email, and it's easier for us to send email from elsewhere in the application (ie subscribable filters).
fields.summary: Make email server settings global

fields.description: It is pointless to have the source because if any changes are made by a customer to their sourcebase they will have to be done every time a new version of JIRA (and the source) is released. It would be reasonable for Atlassian to allow users to submit their bug fixes and improvements as CVS-style patches for inclusion into the next release.
fields.summary: Allow customers who have bought the commercial version w/ source code to submit patches to the source

fields.description:
We have some situations where I would like to notify a number of developers of an issue, e.g. in the event that two people share responsibility of a certain area of the code.

It would be nice to have the ability to either "copy" an assignment to another developer just to notify him of the issue or perhaps to assign an issue to a group of developers.

In the latter case, one might still want to denote one of the developers in the group as being responsible - otherwise everybody thinks the other are solving the issue.
fields.summary: Add the ability to send the issue to one or more users

fields.description:
If a bug is reported in JIRA, and not assigned to anyone, the Assignee is labelled as "Unassigned" and yet the status is labelled as "Assigned".

To have both unassigned and assigned listed for a single issue is a bit odd :)

Maybe need a new 'unassigned, but reported' status?
fields.summary: (un)assigned issues confusing

4: In the same peoject, added issue right - thrown to the login page and no user works, not even the original administrator account given during installation.

(from Thomas Singer)

Hello,

currently the issues for one version are sorted by their priority only.

Wouldn't it make sense to sort them by status, too:

unresolved blocker
resolved blocker
unresolved critical
resolved critical
...

or

unresolved blocker
unresolved critical
resolved blocker
resolved critical


Best regards,
Tom
fields.summary: Sorting in the roadmap
Add "Issues In Progress" report to profile

fields.description:
We have found that the included maillistener is sending out too many emails. E.g. if a developer changes the status of an issue from [Assigned] to [In Progress], he gets a mail himself teling about the change.

I assume I can cirumvent this by making my own listener but it would be nice to have a simple matrix by which the email sending could be configured, e.g.

There are three possible recipients of the emails: The reporter, the assignee and the watchers (those watching the issue).

It ought to be possible to make a matrix where you could link which actions should e mailed to which recipients - as depicted below

---------------------------------------------------------------------

                          Reporter            Assignee       Watchers
Created                                           x
Assigned                                          x              x
Commented                     x                   x              x
Updated                           
Resolved                      x                                  x
Reopened                      x                   x              x
Closed                        x                   x              x

Notify on own changes      [ ] Yes            [x] No

---------------------------------------------------------------------

The last option to avoid, e.g., the one providing comments to get an email with the comments.

However, this would require the database (or a property file) to contain specific listener information which you might prefer to avoid ...
fields.summary: Add the ability to configure mail sending according to actions

This also enables us to have custom fields for different issue types in the future.

fields.description:
When re-assigning an existing issue, the drop down list of assignable users only contains those given by the global 'assignable users' permission. When the global permission for assignable users is blank, the drop down list is empty even though the project 'assignable users' permission is specified.

fields.description:
At the moment we sometimes use key, sometimes use ID in a URL to ViewIssue.

We should always use issue key (where possible / efficient) as it looks nicer for people who copy / paste the URL into an email etc.

Similarly in the browse project reports, we should always include the project ID in the URL, so that people who click on a report and then email it - the emailed URL will work with a single click. 

for example:

http://jira.atlassian.com/secure/BrowseProject.jspa?report=roadmap

won't work in an email but:

http://jira.atlassian.com/secure/BrowseProject.jspa?id=10240&report=roadmap

will.
fields.summary: Improve URLs for copy/paste

fields.description:
Basic time tracking will be in the next 1.3 release.

We've tried to ascertain the main things people want from this feature, and our implementation plan is as follows:
- Time estimation will take the form of a single estimate per issue (ie '5 hours'). 
- Any user with the 'Billable' permission (bad name but I can't think of a better one - anyone?) can then 'log time' against an issue. 
- When users log time they can optionally reduce or change the estimate of time remaining.
fields.summary: Time tracking

fields.description:
Hi.

I had been running JIRA on a linux box (redhat 7.2) with tomcat 4.0.3 and
postgresql 7.1.  We just upgraded the box to redhat 7.3 which included an
upgrade of postgresql to version 7.2.1  There were no changes to the jdk or
to tomcat.   The performance of JIRA on tomcat wasn't so great, so, I
decided to try JIRA on orion.  Wow!  It runs great and is as speedy as can
be!  Unfortunately, I have run into a bit of a problem with posgres and
orion.  I can create issues and perform administrative tasks but I cannot
update any issues.  If I try to add comments, resolve, reopen, edit, or
attach I get an error similar to the following in my web browser but nothing
out of the ordinary in the console:

rator][level,null][created,2002-06-06 13:14:03.526][id,10060]

fields.description:
Make a ServletListener which listens to the web app starting.

The ServletListener should do the following:
- check the OFBiz connection (by querying all projects) and print (to stdout) useful error messages if the connection fails (good for people installing)
- check that all relevant JIRA listeners etc are loaded (IssueCacheListener)
- check the paths (attachment and index) are present

I'm sure there are other things that we can check here - but it will be a very useful tool.

fields.description:
Hi,

We're new to JIRA but are extremely pleased with it so far.  One thing we'd love, that should be there according to the doc, is the ability of a bug reporter to verify that a bug is indeed resolved and to then close that bug.  There doesn't seem to be any way to do this at the moment, however, although 'Closed' is a valid state for an issue.  The only relevant button the reporter sees is 'Reopen'.

Is this feature implemented yet, and if so what could be the reason we don't see it?  I notice that none of the bugs on the JIRA homepage are closed...

Any help would be much appreciated.

Regards,

     Mike

fields.description:
my system is configured to be semi-public. a user would need to login before he can see any of the issues (assuming the appropriate privileges are granted). if anyone tries to open an issue via a URL (something like http://jira.atlassian.com/secure/ViewIssue.jspa?key=JRA-436) would run into a problem if that user is not logged in. the user experience i expect to get from jira is the following:

if an issue is attempted to be opened via a URL, JIRA would check if the user is logged in, if not the log in screen would need to show up. upon successful login, JIRA would tranfer the user to the originally requested issue. currently a user would get a screen that says that the user doesn't have enough permissions to see the issue. this is kind of counter intuitive..
fields.summary: accessing an issue via URL doesn't redirect to the login screen

fields.description:
If a user has create issue permission but not browse permission they cannot see any issues that they have created. They should still be able to see any issues that they have created.

in my install of JIRA a plain user (jira-user group) has the following permissions:

- create issue
- edit issue
- add comment

when someone who belongs just to that group tries to create an issue, they get "permission denied" window, though the issue is created in the DB.

try it for yourself: http://www.themindelectric.net:9000/jira

fields.description:
(from Alex Chudnovsky / dude_wild)

> Ack - I thought I had enough unit tests for all
> cases so I had never looked
> into the providers again since I wrote them. Can you
> provide a test case (or
> set of steps) to recreate? I've never seen this
> happen here. Does it only
> happen when you use the same OSUser from different
> apps? (because exclusive
> access assumes only JIRA will modify the database)

Initially this occured when I was using osUser in a
project that I am  currently developing.  I
encountered a problem when I was trying to create a
certain user which I just deleted, it would not let me
create the user again even though he was not in the
db, I played around for a while, couldnt work out what
was going on, then I restarted resin as that's the
server that I am currently working on, and everything
seemed Ok. However that problem puzzled me; since if
it happened once it may happen again. 

So to solve my situation I started playing around with
JIRA to see if anything wierd happens as I knew you
guys use OsUser and ofbiz in it, all I was doing was
basically creating and deleting users, for about 2
minutes in the row hoping that a similar situation
could happen, strangely enough I could not recreate
the same situation, however I was able to create one
duplicate entry. At this point I realised its probably
the provider caching, as it probably sometimes uses
the cache or sometimes uses the db, and the cache
perhaps somehow either gets bypassed or provides stale
data. That was just my conclusion so I turned it off
and have not been able to recreate the situation
since.
fields.summary: OSUser Caching too much?

/S

When I refreshed the page, the listen was re-added without any information in the Name and Class fields. The delete field was also missing on all the newly added entries.
The content of the database has been verified and there are multiple lines in the listenerconfig table.
